conclusion: To determine the propagation time of light A in the water mist hemisphere, we need to analyze the optical path and use the given information.
The light A enters the water mist hemisphere at an angle of 30 degrees with respect to the interface.
The refractive index of light B is sqrt(2).
Using Snell's Law, 1 * sin 30 degrees = sqrt(2) * sin theta_water mist, leading to sin theta_water mist = 1/(2sqrt(2)).
The light A travels through the water mist hemisphere along a straight line from the entry point to the center O.
The optical path length L is equal to the radius r because the light travels directly to the center.
The speed of light in air is c.
Calculate the speed of light in the water mist: v_water mist = c/sqrt(2).
Calculate the propagation time t = r/v_water mist, leading to t = r/(c/sqrt(2)).
Simplify the expression to get t = r * sqrt(2)/c.
The propagation time of light A in the water mist hemisphere is t = r * sqrt(2)/c.
